text: {"grade": 1, "reasoning": "The criterion requires the response to suggest using 'without prejudice' communications for admissions of fact. While the response does not explicitly use the term 'without prejudice' (which typically relates to settlement negotiations), it strongly advocates for securing a 'no-admission-of-knowledge clause' within the DPA and implementing a 'protective order/confidentiality undertaking' to prevent statements made to HMRC from being used in civil proceedings. This directly addresses the core concern of the criterion: managing admissions of fact made to an authority (HMRC) to protect the client in subsequent litigation (civil suits). Specifically, Section 3.1 includes the clause: 'The Company does not admit any knowledge or participation in the alleged tax evasion. The cooperation is provided solely to assist HMRC in its investigation of third-party fraud,' which is the functional equivalent of controlling admissions of fact in this context.", "criterion_id": "94086a98-120c-465b-b687-a4fa8f63e165"}
